titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Andrew Cropsey letter 1977.669
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:17:47 +0000.

did.abstract: A letter from Andrew G. Cropsey to a Mr. Van Cleef at the Brooklyn Hall of Records regarding a painting of the house of Nicasius DeSille, who lived in the town of New Utrecht (which later became part of the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn). The letter is dated May 26, 1910. Cropsey was a lawyer practicing in Manhattan.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Andrew Cropsey letter, 1977.669, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
